Award.AwardTitle: Invisible Innovators: How the knowledge and experiences of low-income and first-generation students (LIFGs) can contribute to US engineering problem definition and solving

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description:

The goal of this exploratory research is to discover how innovation and creativity in engineering problem solving can be fostered by integrating the knowledge and experiences of low-income and first-generation students (LIFGs) into engineering education. The research team will: 1) engage in an ethnographic analysis of LIFG students' school and work experiences to identify the elements of their knowledge and practice that are the most relevant to engineering; 2) use the ethnographic data to write, pilot, and assess case studies to help engineering educators recognize and value LIFG knowledge and experience in engineering problem definition and solving; and 3) develop and deliver a workshop for faculty at a research university and community college to further theorize where different kinds of engineering knowledge exist in their areas of teaching and practice and how to recognize LIFG students' knowledges and experiences as capabilities in engineering practice.

Broader Significance and Importance:

This research seeks to make LIFGs visible and relevant to engineering education reform. Broadening participation is a key feature of engineering education reform, but dominant definitions of diversity focus on gender, ethnic minorities and persons with disabilities, leaving socioeconomic inequality -- and its link to the other underrepresented demographic categories -- mostly unexamined. The scant research that does exist about LIFGs is grounded in a deficiency model, focusing on what these students lack. This project breaks with the existing scholarship by identifying the ways in which LIFG knowledge and experience outside the classroom, including the tacit knowledge they develop in their lives and at work, could offer innovative ways for all students to define and solve pressing engineering problems. This is a radically different approach to understanding "diversity," as it explicitly includes socioeconomic class background as a potential resource rather than a hindrance. This exploratory, interdisciplinary research lays the foundation to integrate those findings into future work on engineering education research and diversity initiatives.

This Early Concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) proposal is funded through the Broadening Participation in Engineering Program of the Engineering Education and Centers Division and by the Division of Undergraduate Education of the Education and Human Resources Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research is to discover how innovation, creativity and social responsibility in engineering problem solving can be fostered by integrating the knowledge and experiences of low-income and first-generation students (LIFGs) into engineering education. Broadening participation is a key feature of engineering education reform, but dominant definitions of diversity focus on gender, ethnic minorities and persons with disabilities, leaving socioeconomic inequality – and its link to the other underrepresented demographic categories – mostly unexamined. The scant research that does exist about LIFGs is grounded in a deficiency model, focusing on what these students lack and how they need to be fixed. This project breaks with the existing scholarship by identifying the ways in which LIFG knowledge and experiences outside the classroom offers innovative ways for all students to define and solve pressing engineering problems.

Through ethnographic interviews, participant-observation with LIFG students, and two collaborative activities with all students participating in this research, we collaboratively identified the “funds of knowledge” of these students. Funds of knowledge are the skills and ways of being in the world that students hold by virtue of growing up in poor households, working for a living, and continuing to apply in their daily lives, including studying engineering. These funds of knowledge are typically not recognized as valid sources of knowledge in formal classrooms, yet we discovered that the LIFG students’ funds of knowledge were especially valuable to engineering in at least two arenas. First, LIFG students carry, develop and apply funds of knowledge in designing and solving problems in the midst of scarcity, empathizing, and recognizing the sociotechnical nature of engineering problem definition, solving and design. These applications make them effective at making visible the integration of social justice in engineering projects. Second, our students were also able to draw on their funds of knowledge to establish a sense of belonging in key social groups and coping with institutional rites of passage – but only after they challenged dominant understandings of who engineers are and what engineers do. These findings are presented in detail in two scholarly publications:

  • Smith, Jessica M. and Juan Lucena. 2016. Invisible Innovators: How Low Income, First Generation (LIFG) Students Use Their Funds of Knowledge to Belong in Engineering. Engineering Studies 8 (1): 1-26. http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/19378629.2016.1155593
  • Smith, Jessica M. and Juan Lucena. 2016. “How do I show them I’m more than a person who can lift heavy things?” The Funds of Knowledge of Low Income, First Generation Engineering Students. Journal of Women and Minorities in Science and Engineering, 22(3): 199–221. http://dx.doi.org/10.1615/JWomenMinorScienEng.2016015512

Through workshops at our own institution, at other universities around the country, and at national conferences, we intervened into the established modes in which faculty, administrators and staff engage these students, replacing the common deficiency lens with techniques that recognize and build on these students’ capabilities. We also used our classrooms to make socioeconomic inequalities visible to engineering students in general and to teach more privileged students the value of LIFG funds of knowledge to engineering. Making the funds of knowledge of LIFGs visible and relevant to engineering goes beyond redefining “diversity” in the workforce to enhance innovation, creativity and social responsibility by tapping into the creativity of a population that has not had the opportunity to fully contribute to engineering. This is a radically different approach to promoting diversity and broadening participation in engineering, as it explicitly includes socioeconomic class background as a valuable resource rather than a hindrance to be overcome.

This shift in perspective was transformative for the students who participated in our research. They came to view their backgrounds as sources of knowledge to be valued and engaged in their engineering education rather than as liabilities to be hidden or fixed, which empowered them to succeed in their studies as well as their transition to the engineering job market. Our students were able to convert those funds of knowledge into social, cultural and economic capital that they could leverage to attain the research positions, internships and full-time jobs they desired. This exploratory research has laid the foundation for future, larger scale projects that will study the participation of First Gen students in engineering and analyze the specific factors that contribute to their retention and success in engineering.
